newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: South Korean judge muses on justice and coups.
newsitem.headline: South Korean judge muses on justice and coups.

text.p: With a line from the ancient Chinese classics -- "a general who surrenders should not be put to death" -- a South Korean judge on Monday spared the life of former South Korean president Chun Doo Hwan.
Judge Kwon Sung's verdict was intended to send a clear message that coup leaders cannot get away unpunished in a new era of democracy.
But in a summing-up laced with Latin metaphors, Confucian logic and modern notions of justice he made clear South Korea should not set a precedent for an endless cycle of bloody revenge.
"Losing political power doesn't necessarily mean death," Kwon said before setting aside a death sentence for Chun and replacing it with life in jail.

"We must get away from that kind of political culture and establish the principle that death does not follow a transfer of power," he told the 1979 coup leader and architect of the 1980 Kwangju massacre.
"This is as important as punishing the coup."
Chun and his successor Roh Tae-woo were convicted of mutiny and treason over the coup that launched Chun's political career and led to the Kwangju atrocity.
Separately, they were found guilty of amassing hundreds of millions of dollars in slush funds.

Current president Kim Young-sam has been accused by opponents of destroying his two predecessors out of personal vengeance, and there are fears he too may be a target of attack after he steps down in 1998.

Kwon's 55-page ruling was eagerly awaited by South Koreans as possibly the final legal word on a courtroom drama that has poked into the darkest corners of South Korea's brutal history and dragged in a Who's Who of politics and business.
But while Kim's intention was to "right the wrongs of history" -- in the words of Kim who launched the national soul-searching -- he only prolonged the agony for Chun's victims.
"This is obviously a prepared script," sobbed Lee Keum-soon, standing outside the court, after hearing that the most hated man in South Korea had escaped the hangman's noose.
"My son was handicapped during the Kwangju massacre. The people of Kwangju are still living with anger from that incident."
Several hundred people were killed when paratroopers stormed the southern city of Kwangju to put down a citizens' revolt against martial law.
Defence lawyers had argued a successful coup cannot be legally challenged. But the judge slapped down the logic that might is right.
"The fact that an act is legally established does not necessarily mean it is right and unpunishable," he said.
Kwon deflected some of the blame from Roh.
"Although Roh is guilty of similar charges, we have to differentiate between a mastermind and a follower. So I give a 17-year prison sentence," he said, slicing 5-1/2 years off the original sentence.
To five businessmen he allowed to walk free after being convicted of bribing Roh, Kwon offered some solace from the public disgrace and humiliation they have suffered.
The judge suggested the tycoons, who were either acquitted or released on suspended sentences, were caught in the web of corrupt politics where money was power.

"It's not right to put the initial blame on businessmen acting in their company's interests," he said. "Blame should go to the power that forces the companies to pay these bribes and those who help them.
"It costs money to govern the country and politics cost money."
